G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3..proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, placing this matter within the original jurisdiction of the Massachusetts Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and/or 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and/or 8, because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County and the Store where Plaintiff was injured is located in Middlesex County.

G.L. c. 223A.proposition: At all times material hereto, Defendant conducted business in Middlesex County and purposefully availed itself of the privilege of conducting activities in this Commonwealth such that the exercise of jurisdiction comports with G.L. c. 223A and with due process.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).raw_text: Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (abolishing common-law distinction between licensees and invitees and imposing duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: At all relevant times, Plaintiff was a lawful business invitee on Defendant’s premises.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolishes the distinction between licensees and invitees and imposes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors; it does not decide or state that a particular plaintiff was a “business invitee,” nor is that classification relevant after Mounsey. The cited text (a concurrence) critiques continued reliance on trespasser status, and the case as a whole concerns the scope of duty owed to lawful visitors, not whether a given plaintiff qualifies as a business invitee. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition that Plaintiff was a lawful business invitee on Defendant’s premises.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and operator of the Store, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, operation, inspection, maintenance, and control of its premises, including the aisles and walking surfaces, to keep them in a reasonably safe condition for customers.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The case concerns a residential landlord’s duty as a landowner regarding an obviously dangerous trampoline–pool setup, not a commercial storeowner’s duty to maintain aisles and walking surfaces. While the opinion does restate the general Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a duty of reasonable care to lawful entrants and must maintain property in a reasonably safe condition, it neither involves a store nor specifically discusses duties as to store aisles or similar customer areas. Thus it is too contextually different to be proper authority for the specific store‑premises proposition quoted.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973). It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’”

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and operator of the Store, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, operation, inspection, maintenance, and control of its premises, including the aisles and walking surfaces, to keep them in a reasonably safe condition for customers.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.support_reasoning: The case does recite the general rule that an owner or possessor of land owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care, including maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition. However, the holding is focused on rejecting an expanded duty to alter or control an adjacent state highway, not on duties regarding aisles or walking surfaces inside a store. Thus, while it contains a generic premises-liability statement, it does not specifically support the proposition as framed about a store’s internal premises, and is contextually inapposite.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.relevant_excerpt: It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (1988).

See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.raw_text: See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007).
See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.proposition: The visible cart tracks through the spilled milk, the size of the puddle, and the employee’s admission that he had noticed the spill “a few minutes ago” before Plaintiff’s fall further indicate that the condition existed for a sufficient length of time that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, knew or should have known of the spill and either corrected it or warned customers.
See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns constructive notice inferred from facts like cart tracks through spilled milk, the size of the puddle, and an employee’s statement that he noticed the spill minutes earlier. Sheehan does not involve spilled liquid, timing evidence, or employee admissions about a specific spill. Instead, it adopts the mode-of-operation approach and expressly moves away from requiring proof of how long a specific hazard existed. Thus, it does not support a proposition about traditional constructive notice based on duration and physical characteristics of a spill.
See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether an owner has actual or constructive notice in slip and fall cases involving vegetable or fruit matter, an emphasis has been placed on the physical characteristics of the substance to determine how long it had been left on the floor. … [T]he plaintiff urges this court to adopt the mode of operation approach, enabling plaintiffs in slip and fall cases to prove that a store owner either had constructive or actual notice of a dangerous condition on the premises if the owner could reasonably foresee the existence of a dangerous condition on the premises… We agree.”

G.L. c. 231..proposition: Plaintiff has complied, to the extent applicable, with the provisions of Massachusetts law governing the commencement of civil actions for personal injury, including but not limited to G.L. c. 231.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.raw_text: Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973); Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154 (2013).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor of land owes a duty to all lawful visitors to act as a reasonable person in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of avoiding the risk.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolished the invitee/licensee distinction and adopted a unified standard of care: possessors of land owe all lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care in maintaining the premises, evaluated in light of factors including likelihood and seriousness of injury and the burden of avoiding the risk. Dos Santos reaffirmed and applied this standard. The quoted Kaplan concurrence does not contradict that core holding and is part of the decision that established the proposition, so the cases support the stated rule under Massachusetts law.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.relevant_excerpt: We hold that the common law distinctions between licensees and invitees shall no longer be recognized in this Commonwealth. The duty owed by an occupier of land should be to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk. This duty should extend to all lawful visitors.

See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.raw_text: See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 782–83 (2007); Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973).
See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and/or operator of the Store open to the public, owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition; to inspect for unsafe conditions; to correct unsafe conditions within a reasonable time; and to warn lawful visitors of any dangers of which it knew or should have known.
See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reiterates Massachusetts’ traditional premises-liability rule that a store owner must maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition, with reasonable opportunity to discover and correct hazards, and does so in the context of a store open to the public. Although the case ultimately adopts the mode-of-operation doctrine to modify how notice may be shown, it affirms that the underlying duty is to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe, inspect, correct hazards within a reasonable time, and protect/warn invitees about dangers the owner knows or should know about.
See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets,.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … [T]he law has afforded store owners a reasonable opportunity to discover and correct any hazards before liability attaches. … [P]remises liability attaches only if a store owner has actual or constructive notice of the existence of the dangerous condition, sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition.”

See Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 786\u201388 (d.raw_text: See Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 786–88 (discussing reasonable measures to discover and remedy transitory hazards); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 376–77 (2010).
See Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 786\u201388 (d.proposition: Defendant further owed a duty to implement and enforce reasonable policies and procedures for the regular inspection, cleanup, and maintenance of floors; for the timely correction of spills; and for the placement of adequate warnings when hazardous conditions existed or were reasonably foreseeable.
See Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 786\u201388 (d.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care to protect against hazards, including snow and ice, and expressly grounds that duty in Restatement § 343, which encompasses reasonable inspection, maintenance, and protective measures. The opinion explains that owners must take reasonable efforts to protect visitors from known or reasonably knowable dangerous conditions (analogizing to cases like Sheehan involving spills), which by implication includes implementing and enforcing reasonable policies for inspection, cleanup, timely correction, and warnings. Thus it supports the proposition that defendants owe such a duty as part of reasonable premises-care obligations.
See Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 786\u201388 (d.relevant_excerpt: If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger. See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, 448 Mass. 780, 782-784 (2007); Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (1965).

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant further owed a duty to implement and enforce reasonable policies and procedures for the regular inspection, cleanup, and maintenance of floors; for the timely correction of spills; and for the placement of adequate warnings when hazardous conditions existed or were reasonably foreseeable.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The decision abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation rule and holds that landowners owe lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care as to snow and ice, analogous to other hazards. However, it does not specifically address or articulate a distinct duty to implement and enforce internal policies and procedures for regular inspection, cleanup, maintenance of floors, timely correction of spills, or placement of warnings. The opinion speaks at a higher level of general duty and leaves the specifics of reasonable care to the fact finder, so it does not serve as authority for the detailed procedural duties stated in the proposition.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 56 (1983) (duty of reasonable care includes taking reasonable precautions against foreseeable risks).
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: This constitutes actual notice to Defendant through its employee-agent.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether something constituted actual notice to the defendant through its employee-agent. The excerpted opinion (a dissent focused on causation, foreseeability, and speculative proof) does not address notice, agency, or communication of information to the defendant at all. Instead, it analyzes proximate cause and foreseeability in a premises-liability context, so it does not support the claimed notice proposition.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

See Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 786\u201387 (d.raw_text: See Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 786–87 (discussing constructive notice and methods to infer duration of hazard).

Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 788\u201389; Papad.raw_text: Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 788–89; Papadopoulos, 457 Mass. at 375–77.
Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 788\u201389; Papad.proposition: The risk that a customer will slip and fall on spilled liquid in a supermarket aisle is foreseeable as a matter of common experience, and Massachusetts law requires reasonable measures to protect against such risks.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85..proposition: In any event, Plaintiff’s conduct, if deemed negligent in any respect, was not greater than the negligence of Defendant, and any damages shall be diminished only in proportion to any negligence attributed to Plaintiff pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85.

Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.proposition: In any event, Plaintiff’s conduct, if deemed negligent in any respect, was not greater than the negligence of Defendant, and any damages shall be diminished only in proportion to any negligence attributed to Plaintiff pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85.
Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses how a plaintiff’s negligence affects recovery in a negligence action under G.L. c. 231, § 85, distinguishing it from the absolute bar in warranty via the Correia doctrine. The court explains that in negligence, a plaintiff is barred only if his negligence is greater than that of the defendants, and otherwise his damages are merely diminished in proportion to his fault—precisely the comparative negligence rule stated in the proposition.
Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: “Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).” (403 Mass. at 62–63.)

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: “Proximate cause” under Massachusetts law requires that the negligence be a substantial contributing factor in producing the harm.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses proximate cause in terms of foreseeability and intervening/superseding causes, not in terms of whether the negligence was a “substantial contributing factor.” The court describes proximate cause as turning on foreseeability and policy-based limits on factual causation, without using or endorsing the substantial-factor formulation. Thus, while the case addresses proximate cause, it does not state that proximate cause requires the negligence to be a substantial contributing factor in producing the harm.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. See Wallace v. Ludwig, 292 Mass. 251, 254 (1935). Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978). In this respect, proximate cause prevents liability from being based on factual causation alone.”

G.L. c. 233, \u00a7 79G (admissibility o.raw_text: G.L. c. 233, § 79G (admissibility of medical and hospital records and bills).
G.L. c. 233, \u00a7 79G (admissibility o.proposition: See G.L. c. 233, § 79G (admissibility of medical and hospital records and bills).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F (recognizing dam.proposition: See G.L. c. 231, § 60F (recognizing damages for pain and suffering in personal injury actions).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B (prejudgment inte.raw_text: G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in tort actions).
G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B (prejudgment inte.proposition: See G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest in tort actions).

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871\u.raw_text: Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871–72 (1991) (recognizing damages for loss of enjoyment of life as part of pain and suffering).
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871\u.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered and will in the future suffer loss of enjoyment of life arising from the injuries caused by Defendant’s negligence.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871\u.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses emotional distress damages and other forms of personal injury recoverable under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A, and briefly notes that Gonzalez experienced "various physical pains," but it does not separately identify, analyze, or label "loss of enjoyment of life" as a distinct element or component of pain and suffering damages. The case is primarily about intentional infliction of emotional distress and consumer protection remedies, not about recognizing loss of enjoyment of life as a category of damages. As such, it does not clearly support the specific proposition that plaintiff has suffered and will suffer loss of enjoyment of life arising from defendant’s negligence.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 871\u.relevant_excerpt: "As a consequence of this conduct, Gonzalez became frightened of Haddad, and she felt 'angry, alone, helpless ... withdrawn ... [and] spent extended periods alone in her room, often crying.' Gonzalez also experienced 'various physical pains which may be reasonably attributable to the tensions and stress caused by her living conditions.' In these circumstances... the judge was justified in concluding that Gonzalez had made out a common law case of intentional infliction of emotional distress."

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 319–20 (2002).
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: Defendant is vicariously liable, under the doctrine of respondeat superior, for the negligent acts and omissions of its employees, agents, and/or servants, including but not limited to the employee who observed the spill and failed to take prompt corrective action, because such acts and omissions occurred within the course and scope of their employment and in furtherance of Defendant’s business.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that an employer is vicariously liable under respondeat superior for the negligent acts of its employee committed within the scope of employment, and that no special control over the details of the employee’s professional decisions is required. Although the facts involve physician malpractice rather than a premises employee failing to clean a spill, the legal principle is the same: once an employer–employee relationship is established, the employer may be liable for negligence occurring in the course and scope of employment in furtherance of the employer’s business.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: “Broadly speaking, respondeat superior is the proposition that an employer, or master, should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee, or servant, committed within the scope of employment… To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA…. Once an employer-employee relationship is established… [a]ll that remains to be determined is whether the tort occurred within the scope of employment.”

See G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 6F; G..proposition: Plaintiff seeks fair and reasonable compensation for all such damages, and such additional damages as may be shown at trial, together with statutory interest, costs, and such other relief as the Court deems just and proper. See G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B, 6F; G.L. c. 235, § 8.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B and \u00a7 6C;.proposition: Prejudgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B and § 6C;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38 and G.L. c. 231, § 60, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
